title: Why is it important to set the significance level of a test before doing the test? - Quora

response.answer_text: Assuming you are discussing a statistical test of significance - the significance (rejection) level should be set before seeing the data and doing the test otherwise it casts serious doubt on the validity of the test. That’s because setting the significance level after doing the test lets one adjust it to get the desired conclusion. Then the conclusion can’t be trusted. E.g. if the result is p > .05 , hmm, but it’s p < .10, then if one really wants to reject the null hypothesis, one can say “the null. hypothesis is rejected at the p < .10 level

My take is to ask why perform a test if there is no epsilon of tolerance firmly established beforehand? To visualize this, there is no 100 percent one-foot rulers that roll off the assembly line with an exact length of one foot. Carver Wrightman alias Cecil R. Williams
